bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, July 16, 1942

div1.p: Hench discusses his military duty, noting that will be assigned to Fort Custer, then Fort Carson. He has found the original fever charts of the yellow fever cases in the possession of Mrs. Ames and is now studying them.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, July 16, 1942
div1.p:
Thank you so much for the nice blotters. They are very attractive
and I expect to send them around to some of my interested friends and yellow
fever people.

I have Morrow's book and was interested indeed to note the Cornwell
painting therein. Also the painting was reprinted in the New York Times book
review; at least I think it was the Times. Maybe it was the Herald Tribune.

Thanks for the camp directors. My boy, Kahler, especially was
glad to have one giving the various ranks and army camps. Unless my orders
are changed I will leave here this Monday for Fort Custer for about six
weeks' preliminary training before going to my permanent station at Camp
Carson, Colorado Springs. Fort Custer is on your map but not Camp Carson.

I have just turned up the original fever charts of the yellow
fever cases which disappeared from the Surgeon General's office years ago
without any record of where they had gone. I found them in the possession
of Mrs. Ames, Dr. Ames' widow, and how have them here at the Clinic for
study. So it goes. I am turning up things constantly.

I will keep you informed of my whereabouts and the Clinic address
will always reach me. Please let me hear from you about the progress of
your work. I will be happier than ever to have letters while in camp.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. Mr. George A. Kellogg
41 East 42nd Street
New York City
